"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body:
I think so, unless there is an annihilation that completely destroys all consciousness making it no longer possible to turn around.

On an unrelated note, in my opinion "will not be forgiven" in this case also refers to those in a state of continually rejecting the holy spirit, not those who have in the past and have now repented. Remember Jesus brought it up because some Pharisees had been doing so, and he was trying to convince them to stop, which would be pointless if their fate had already been sealed right then and there.

post.title: Do you believe sins can be forgiven even after death

body:
with Catholicism there are the related concepts of praying for the dead, purgatory, and indulgences

and a belief of two kinds of punishment of sin, I think: there's the eternal heaven or hell reward or punishment depending on repenting of sin, and then there's a lesser punishment attached to each sin done - the lesser punishment can be forgiven after death by the actions of other people. 

The idea was that if a person dies and is going to go to heaven, but still has these lesser punishments, then they go to purgatory temporarily. Once a person is dead, they can do nothing more to help themselves. They can pray to help others on earth, maybe (if in heaven or purgatory)? But if they are in purgatory, I think they're dependent on the help of others to pray or do something to obtain indulgences for their relief.
